B.U.R.P. Brandishes
Balto's Blemishes
By C. C. RIDER
Once again Coucher women have opened their hearts and
mouths to aid in the fight for human dignity. -We feel everyone has a right to live and work" said a spokesman for the newly
formed Human Dignity Committee (HOC.). "The first step,
however, is a compulsive change in the structure of society." Baltimore has been selected as the pilot city for a new attack on
Negroes.

W. Groucher, Goucher Coucher

Marianne Moore: Old Poetess Rips Thumb from Dyke
Insectlike on the combined
4 S's of Mrs. Howe, Miss deand the poet herself,
Ford
Marianne Moore descended the
stairs of Kraushaaaar Auditorium on Tuesday evening and
began a reading of poetry
Which proved, in the words of
her poem, "the mind is an enChanting thing."
Miss Moore's poetry, read
over the new sound system of
Kraushaaaaar, was broadcast
aver the entire campus, and
oftentimes volleyball games or
3howers were interrupted during the evening as the particiPants stopped to hear such
lines as "The musk ox has no
autsk and it is not an ox—
illiterate epithet." Miss Moore
wore a smart, two-piece Dior
with darling white boots and a
charming Chanel hat with veil.
' gloves were of softest kid,
lie,

as was her girdle. She chewed

a cigar.
By the time she had finished
her selections for the evening,
Miss Moore had completely
won the hearts of all present,
and some were so enthused as
to put aside their New Yorkers
long enough to applaud such
lines as "When the lain creeps
and."
One undergraduate's statement best, sums up the way we
at Goucher felt after the lilting
reading. She said: "Miss Moore
may be an old lady, but she's
quite cute. Insectlike, you
know?"
The reading was the fourth
in the annual Goucher Bystander Series of Poetry. Coffee and Cake. Previous evenings included: Robert Lowell,
who wore a Brooks Brothers
suit and a tie with a picture of

the Statue of Liberty on it; J.
D. Salinger, who doesn't write
poetry, but wore Supp-Hose
socks and a black garret belt
with a cow's head buckle; T. S.
Elliot, who is dead, but always
welcome to the Goucher campus; and Robert, The Talking
Dog. On March 14, Allen Ginsberg and LeFtoi Jones read to
each other in a date-room of
Heubeck Hall, but that was an
event in the Look, Listen and
Giggle Poetry Series.
Last night, though,- was all
Marianne Moore. The Reading
was broadcast live into selected Baltimore slums, as part
of the Goucher College—Community Project to Keep Children Off the Streets Series,
sponsored by the Goucher girls
the
themselves, who earn
money by reading their poetry
In bus stations and drug stores.

now gets a chance to compete
against several hundred other
'worst dressed girls' in the
national finals run by Wontan's Wear Daily.

Gouchk ins Loose,
Goose Mongoose
Dr. Hugo C. Paisiey, noted
Goucher psychologist, has announced the completion of a
two year psychological experiment done under the auspices
of the Goucher College Paychology Experiment Grant.
The experiment required the
cooperation of 15 Goucher
psychology students, and used
the "double blind" method of
experimentation. (An example
of the "double blind" method
would be the administering of
a new drug without the subject
or the experimentor knowing
that the drug was, in actuality,
being administered. This is
done so as to be able to obtain
both reactions and observations
unhindered by preconceived
notions).
Dr. Paisley explained his
particular experiment thusly:
"15 students were required, at
different intervals, to observe
the erotic movements of the
southeastern Australian mongoose. They were to take copious notes on what they saw.
The trick was that the mongoose did not know why he was
being watched, and the experimenter did not know why he
was watching the mongoose."
(This is undoubtedly Dr. Paisley's usage of the "double
blind" method). "After two
years I compiled the notes,"
Dr. Paisley continued, "and
tried .to 'determine just how
(Continued on Pige 2)

Goucher volunteers will be
working with ex-CORE members from Local No. 1 of the
Baltimore Union of the Radical Proleteriat 'B.U.R.P.).
"Governor Tawes and Mayor
McKeldin have no idea of
what's going on in Baltimore."
said FiFi Whitewash, a chaster
member of the group. "I know
because I've been there, twice."
Miss Whitewash had indeed
participated , in the annual
Goucher Bus Tour of Baltimore for two years running.
"In conclusion." concluded
FiFi. "we are organizing to
fight, and organization is the
key to victory. We've done it
before, and we will do it again."
Miss Whitewash was applauded
heartily by six to eight passers
by who had stopped to listen
to the interview.
The idea of organization was
born last year in regions of
the deep South where members of the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party (m.r.
D.P.). began to organize organizations. If black workers
were brought together, they
reasoned, then they would be
organized. Thus organized they
would be in a position to buy
a secona hasd mimeograph
machine and get some buttons
printed up.
Initially the group encountered resistance. It was found
that many of the black workers did not speak English.
Some complained that the
mimeograph machine, with a
prominent crank, reminded
them of a cotton gin and
others thought that Union referred to the Civil War.
The new Goucher Human
Dignity Committee (G.H.D.0 )
is willing to tackle the job.
however. The first order of
business will be a March to
Towson on Wednesday to protest the Pixie Pizza Shops exploitation of an Italian stereotype, the Pizza. They invite all
Interested to join them. A
mixer will follow.

GOUCHER WEEKLY

PAGE TWO

Poetess Limply Lauds Love Poetry;
Asserts New Ewe Knew You Too
Goucher girls swarmed the
college center lecture hall last
Thursday as poetess Melvina
Limply addressed the student
body. Although the New School
poetess spoke on love, "she had
one of the largest turnouts of
this academic year", said Hillary D. Box, spokeswoman for
the New School readers.
"I'm a poetess--that's with
two a's," opened the free
verser. I was named Melvina
after my aunt, that's on the
Montana side, after my aunt's
prized ewe. She used to treat
it like one of the family, she
used to say, jokingly.
Well,
that's where my career in
poetry started — indirectly, of
course."
Miss Limply went on to explain the singular poetic sensitivity that had driven her aunt
to breed ewes. "It was a great
hardship to leave her quiet
bungalow in Park Heights and
go out there," she lulled on.
"But, then she was a singular
woman.."
The obvious emotion packed
behind these intimate revelations deeply affected the hushed
audience. "When you hear of
a great human being making

an artistic sacrifice like that,
it makes you want to go out
and do it too," a Goucher
freshman was quoted as saying.
"But the sacrifice of an
artist does not stop here. I go
all about the Baltimore Metropolitan area, even in outlying areas of the state, and
preach the love of the New
Poetry," said Miss Limply
afterwards. "Next month I'm
going to speak at Loyola."
Where does the sacrifice of
the Poet end? "NO, not at
Goucher," she said in answer
to Miss Box's question. "I'm
going to go on and on and on
till I stop loving," she continued.
And all this started with—
well, you know.

experiment, because he feels
that they "would not be in the
best interests of the university."

Re: K.L.G.'s Parting Shot
We know where you are, and
we knew what you did! And
we're coming in to get you. if
its "not too far to walk," that
is. So come on out with your
heads up.
Wendy, John and Michael
might have flown out the window of the nursery but they
were children and you MUNt
be one too.
For just suppose that Nana

stiff and might knock hell out
of any sort of FREEEEdom you
might have enjoyed had you
been silent.
If you're so hip why aren't
you dead?

The Plow Chemical Corporation recently announced the
development of a Birth Control
chewing gum which they will
manufacture in co-operation
with Fleer, makers of Dubble
Bubble. The gum will come in
four flavors, cherry, apple,
peach and chocolate, and will
be packaged in many shapes
and sizes. Its effectiveness has
not as yet been ascertained,
and tests will be run at Gouther
College in connection With an
extra curricular course in traffic safety.

Up And Afom
Tile 'anger of the Vietnamese conflict building
to a global war is obvious to all. There is, however,
a more important policy decision undertaken by both
the American anti Soviet Governments that equally insures the eventuality of a Third World War.
A recent report was made public in the Baltimore
Sun which stated that large technical complexes, known
to he an implementation of a ballistic missile defense
system, were recently installed about Moscow and Leningrad. The American Government has also displayed
intentions of developing a similar system.
Such a policy insures the extension of the arms
race. For if both governments were sincerely interested
in containing th arms race then they would avoid further
expenditures, especially expenditures that necessarily
would force a reexamination of the effectiveness of their
current offensive postures.
A new system Id anti-missile batteries does nothing
In protect either nation, for what it succeeds in doing is
providing an additional dimension in which to continue
the arms race.
Currently the American position is analagous to
a ViTestern showdown in which the Soviets have a pistol
and we have a machine gun. Both possess the ability to
kill, only efficiency is a variable factor. If one side
chooses to adopt a bullet proof vest, then the other side
could just justifiably question the other's intentions as
to its eventual use. A billion dollar vest that encourages
suspicion and competition while still leaving the head
and feet unprotected is a foolhardy form of insurance.
The United States, possessing the upper hand, must,
naturally keep her offensive capability strong. It is in
the interest of peace that we make it clear to the Soviets
that no form of defense is enough to insure protection.
But at the same time we must be willing to leave our
population vulnerable to the Soviet missile system, thus
maintaining an effective balance of power.
The strategic gains of a new defensive missile svstem are far outweighed by the political consequence of
forcing both nations into an unavoidable and dangerous
second round of arms competition.
While it is vital that the American college student
continue to examine the violent issue of Vietnam, it is
also important that We do not lose sight of the more
basic issue of arms control.

The Dodge Boys
The forthcoming administration of the Selective
Service College Qualification test invites a public reappraisal of some of the other methods being employed
to determine student classification for the draft. As for
the examination itself, while it introduces a levelling
factor into the selection process, the Net that ii is not
mandatory to reduce the acceptability of the test as a
universal guideline.
Undoubtedly, the most serious issue is that of the
reclassification to 1-A status of student demonstrators
against the war in Viet Nam. Such action has been based
upon a ten-year old law directing that violators of the
Selective Service law be given primacy in eligibility for
the draft.
General Hershey, direeior of the Selective Service,
has expressed at various limes his belief that such demonstrators "should be spanked," and that they should be
drafted immediately.'These remarks bring to mind an
incongruous picture: unable to spank thee allegedly
errant crusaders, Hershey instead proposeS to Bend them
off to war, in this manner making them see the error
of their ways.
Perhaps the most dangerous concept of regarding
the draft as punishment, is the fact that when one person
is conscripted for disciplinary purposes it necessarily
supposes that whomever is drafted is in effect punished.
Stack a system does not make for an effective moral
climate nor for an effective army.

Are we making progress in

the introduction of nuclear

(democracy vs.' communism) to

limited meaning. The stability
of national powers no longer exists. With a few ICBM's and
some delivery capability, Switzerland would become a serious
and determined national power
—especially if they had a leader
like Charles de Gaulle. But such
discussion is hypothetical and
mainly for dreamers. We must
differentiate between long and
short run goals. In the short run
our policy is and will be successful. As usual, the long run
effects are unknown and remain
Questionable. '

no mercy from their own Communist party.

foreign critics of U.S. policy in
Viet Nam were in unanimous
chorus declaring that one consequence of the U.S. decision to
defend South Viet Nam was
bound to happen: it would end
the Sino-Soviet feud and drive
Moscow and Peking back into
each other's arms. It did just the
Opposite.
"Japan—Twelve months ago
Japan was moving toward a new
modus vivendi with Red China

Alex Sotir, of Wesleyan College, Will replace Wilson Fewster
as head football coach here, Athletic Director Marshall Turner
announced today.
Fewster will retire at the end of this year to take advantage
of a business opportunity.
Sotir's appointment will become effective on July 1. He is currently line
coach for Wesleyan's grid squad and
mentors varsity lacrosse and wrestling
there.
After graduating from Springfield
College, in Masachusetts, in 1954.
Sotir served four years in the Navy.
He then joined the MIT athletic staff,
where he was varsity wrestling, freshman track, and later assistant lacrosse
coach.
"We're pleased to get a man of this
caliber from a school with the same
athletic outlook as ours," Turner remarked.
Fewster, who was a student here
before joining the coaching staff, has
been with Hopkins since February of
1951.
After two years, he left to go into
ALEX SOTIR
business but returned later to lead
To replace Fewster

in 1959 and 1960.

Trying to rebound from a
stunning 12-10 upset at the
hands of Yale, the varsity lacrosse team travels to Princeton,

League co-champion Tigers.
"Our men are anxious to come
back and play four good guartens," noted Jay coach Bob
Scott. "We've practiced harder
this week than we have yet this
season, and we have to be ready
for Princeton tomorrow."
The Tiger roster lists eleven
returning lettermen, including
third team All-America defensemen John Baker, and highly
touted midfielder Marty Eichelberger. Other key Princeton
players include 6'2", 190 lb.
crease attackman Bob Mueller,
middle Ward Coe; senior attackman John Nixdorf; and senior
goalie Graeme Flan6ers, who had
22 saves in the Tigers' 12-7 loss
to Maryland last weekend.

has a good-sized team. They

Dr. Hugo C. Paisiey, noted
Goucher psychologist, has announced the completion of a
two year psychological experiment done under the auspices
of the Goucher College Paychology Experiment Grant.
The experiment required the
cooperation of 15 Goucher
psychology students, and used
the "double blind" method of
experimentation. (An example
of the "double blind" method
would be the administering of
a new drug without the subject
or the experimentor knowing
that the drug was, in actuality,
being administered. This is
done so as to be able to obtain
both reactions and observations
unhindered by preconceived
notions).
Dr. Paisley explained his
particular experiment thusly:
"15 students were required, at
different intervals, to observe
the erotic movements of the
southeastern Australian mongoose. They were to take copious notes on what they saw.
The trick was that the mongoose did not know why he was
being watched, and the experimenter did not know why he
was watching the mongoose."
(This is undoubtedly Dr. Paisley's usage of the "double
blind" method). "After two
years I compiled the notes,"
Dr. Paisley continued, "and
tried .to 'determine just how

Poetess Limply Lauds Love Poetry;
Asserts New Ewe Knew You Too
Goucher girls swarmed the
college center lecture hall last
Thursday as poetess Melvina
Limply addressed the student
body. Although the New School
poetess spoke on love, "she had
one of the largest turnouts of
this academic year", said Hillary D. Box, spokeswoman for
the New School readers.
"I'm a poetess--that's with
two a's," opened the free
verser. I was named Melvina
after my aunt, that's on the
Montana side, after my aunt's
prized ewe. She used to treat
it like one of the family, she
used to say, jokingly.
Well,
that's where my career in
poetry started — indirectly, of
course."
Miss Limply went on to explain the singular poetic sensitivity that had driven her aunt
to breed ewes. "It was a great
hardship to leave her quiet
bungalow in Park Heights and
go out there," she lulled on.
"But, then she was a singular
woman.."
The obvious emotion packed
behind these intimate revelations deeply affected the hushed
audience. "When you hear of
a great human being making

an artistic sacrifice like that,
it makes you want to go out
and do it too," a Goucher
freshman was quoted as saying.
"But the sacrifice of an
artist does not stop here. I go
all about the Baltimore Metropolitan area, even in outlying areas of the state, and
preach the love of the New
Poetry," said Miss Limply
afterwards. "Next month I'm
going to speak at Loyola."
Where does the sacrifice of
the Poet end? "NO, not at
Goucher," she said in answer
to Miss Box's question. "I'm
going to go on and on and on
till I stop loving," she continued.
And all this started with—
well, you know.

Up And Afom
Tile 'anger of the Vietnamese conflict building
to a global war is obvious to all. There is, however,
a more important policy decision undertaken by both
the American anti Soviet Governments that equally insures the eventuality of a Third World War.
A recent report was made public in the Baltimore
Sun which stated that large technical complexes, known
to he an implementation of a ballistic missile defense
system, were recently installed about Moscow and Leningrad. The American Government has also displayed
intentions of developing a similar system.
Such a policy insures the extension of the arms
race. For if both governments were sincerely interested
in containing th arms race then they would avoid further
expenditures, especially expenditures that necessarily
would force a reexamination of the effectiveness of their
current offensive postures.
A new system Id anti-missile batteries does nothing
In protect either nation, for what it succeeds in doing is
providing an additional dimension in which to continue
the arms race.
Currently the American position is analagous to
a ViTestern showdown in which the Soviets have a pistol
and we have a machine gun. Both possess the ability to
kill, only efficiency is a variable factor. If one side
chooses to adopt a bullet proof vest, then the other side
could just justifiably question the other's intentions as
to its eventual use. A billion dollar vest that encourages
suspicion and competition while still leaving the head
and feet unprotected is a foolhardy form of insurance.
The United States, possessing the upper hand, must,
naturally keep her offensive capability strong. It is in
the interest of peace that we make it clear to the Soviets
that no form of defense is enough to insure protection.
But at the same time we must be willing to leave our
population vulnerable to the Soviet missile system, thus
maintaining an effective balance of power.
The strategic gains of a new defensive missile svstem are far outweighed by the political consequence of
forcing both nations into an unavoidable and dangerous
second round of arms competition.
While it is vital that the American college student
continue to examine the violent issue of Vietnam, it is
also important that We do not lose sight of the more
basic issue of arms control.

Service College Qualification test invites a public reappraisal of some of the other methods being employed
to determine student classification for the draft. As for
the examination itself, while it introduces a levelling
factor into the selection process, the Net that ii is not
mandatory to reduce the acceptability of the test as a
universal guideline.
Undoubtedly, the most serious issue is that of the
reclassification to 1-A status of student demonstrators
against the war in Viet Nam. Such action has been based
upon a ten-year old law directing that violators of the
Selective Service law be given primacy in eligibility for
the draft.
General Hershey, direeior of the Selective Service,
has expressed at various limes his belief that such demonstrators "should be spanked," and that they should be
drafted immediately.'These remarks bring to mind an
incongruous picture: unable to spank thee allegedly
errant crusaders, Hershey instead proposeS to Bend them
off to war, in this manner making them see the error
of their ways.
Perhaps the most dangerous concept of regarding
the draft as punishment, is the fact that when one person
is conscripted for disciplinary purposes it necessarily
supposes that whomever is drafted is in effect punished.
Stack a system does not make for an effective moral
climate nor for an effective army.

VIETNAM: FAILURE OR ACHIEVEMENT? y

Are we making progress in
Viet Nam? Some critics of the
present policy say that if we
win, we will lose; and if we lose,
we will win. I'm afraid that with
the introduction of nuclear
weapons and political ideology
(democracy vs.' communism) to
the world scene, victory or defeat in military terms has a very
limited meaning. The stability
of national powers no longer exists. With a few ICBM's and
some delivery capability, Switzerland would become a serious
and determined national power
—especially if they had a leader
like Charles de Gaulle. But such
discussion is hypothetical and
mainly for dreamers. We must
differentiate between long and
short run goals. In the short run
our policy is and will be successful. As usual, the long run
effects are unknown and remain
Questionable. '
I owe the following list of
positive political achievements in
S.E. Asia to the distinguished
columnist Roscoe Drummond, of
N. Y. Herald-Tribune,
the
3/16,166.
'Laos—Twelve months ago the
Laotian Communists were a
mounting peril to the government. Today they are badly
splintered.
"Cambodia — Twelve months
ago it seemed that Prince

Sihanouck was trying to win
merit points with the Communists as a hedge against the
future. Today he is warning his
own people that, if North Viet
Nam prevails, they can expect
no mercy from their own Communist party.
"Philippines—Twelve months
ago the Philippines were wracked with riots in protest against
even the small support the government was giving Saigon. Now
the government is preparing to
send troops.
"Korea—Twelve months -ago
Korea had contributed only
token forces to the defense of
South Viet Nam. Now it is at
the point of bringing the total
of its combat troops there to
44,000—more in proportion to its
population of 28,500,000, than
the U.S. itself.
"Peking-Moscow — Twelve
months ago the American and
foreign critics of U.S. policy in
Viet Nam were in unanimous
chorus declaring that one consequence of the U.S. decision to
defend South Viet Nam was
bound to happen: it would end
the Sino-Soviet feud and drive
Moscow and Peking back into
each other's arms. It did just the
Opposite.
"Japan—Twelve months ago
Japan was moving toward a new
modus vivendi with Red China

"The Difference" will launch
its fund raising drive immediately after spring vacation. The
committee will concentrate on

The Boys from Syracuse April
22, 23, 24 by the Barnstormers.
The funds collected during the
drive will be used to make up
the "difference" between the
scholarship money now available
to underprivileged students accepted by the Admissions Office
and the money that these students need to be able to afford
Hopkins. According to James L.
Bowman, Director of Financial
Aid, the program will help those
who will need $3,000 or more to
come to Hopkins.
Program Endorsed ..
Both the Admissions and
Financial Aid Offices have endorsed the program. Bowman
stated, "I think it's a very good
prograrn and a good idea they've
come up with. We've appreciated
the interest they've taken in
broadening the socio-economic
base of the campus.
"This is a problem Mr. Bilgrave (Director of Admissions)
and I have taken interest in
for a number of years, but the
resources just haven't been
available before. It has been a
matter of putting your eggs all
In one basket or spreading them
around."
Bowman emphasized that the
Difference program will not affect the regular scholarship program, but will supplement it by
using new resources available
from the government. He has already received
approval of
$25.000 in funds from the Eduoational Opportunities Grant
Program and is expecting an additional $20,000 from the federal
Work-Study program .
The latter program would
create jobs on campus "over and
above" the present work program on campus, such as tutoring positions. He stated that
eventually he hoped Hopkins
would reach the level of some
of the Ivy League schools where
assistance can be guaranteed to

anyone who needs it.

outgrowth of the Hopkins Basic

that American newsmen in the
thirty-five
last
years have

in presenting news objectively,
and stop envisioning themselves
as amateur foreign citizens." lie
further stated that since America has made such a definite
commitment in Viet-Nam, it
must win the war there.

there have been six general types
of mistakes which U.S. newspapermen have committed in
foreign reporting.

of Stalin's regime in the 1930's
by a New York Times' correspondent in Moscow.

government so that he could remain in Moscow, and therefore
completely deceived the American people for a decade and a
half on Russian internal affairs.

Alex Sotir, of Wesleyan College, Will replace Wilson Fewster
as head football coach here, Athletic Director Marshall Turner
announced today.
Fewster will retire at the end of this year to take advantage
of a business opportunity.
Sotir's appointment will become effective on July 1. He is currently line
coach for Wesleyan's grid squad and
mentors varsity lacrosse and wrestling
there.
After graduating from Springfield
College, in Masachusetts, in 1954.
Sotir served four years in the Navy.
He then joined the MIT athletic staff,
where he was varsity wrestling, freshman track, and later assistant lacrosse
coach.
"We're pleased to get a man of this
caliber from a school with the same
athletic outlook as ours," Turner remarked.
Fewster, who was a student here
before joining the coaching staff, has
been with Hopkins since February of
1951.
After two years, he left to go into
ALEX SOTIR
business but returned later to lead
To replace Fewster
Hopkins to conference football titles
in 1959 and 1960.

By JOHN M. BRICKMAN
Trying to rebound from a
stunning 12-10 upset at the
hands of Yale, the varsity lacrosse team travels to Princeton,
N.J., tomorrow to face the Ivy
League co-champion Tigers.
"Our men are anxious to come
back and play four good guartens," noted Jay coach Bob
Scott. "We've practiced harder
this week than we have yet this
season, and we have to be ready
for Princeton tomorrow."
The Tiger roster lists eleven
returning lettermen, including
third team All-America defensemen John Baker, and highly
touted midfielder Marty Eichelberger. Other key Princeton
players include 6'2", 190 lb.
crease attackman Bob Mueller,
middle Ward Coe; senior attackman John Nixdorf; and senior
goalie Graeme Flan6ers, who had
22 saves in the Tigers' 12-7 loss
to Maryland last weekend.
Tight Tiger Defense
Scott noted that "Princeton
has a good-sized team. They
